dc:description:
The NOD2 gene is located on chromosome 16 at 16q12.1 and encodes the nucleotide-binding oligomerization domain-containing protein 2, a member of the NOD-like receptor family. NOD2 is a cytoplasmic pattern recognition receptor and plays an important role in regulating the innate immune response. The NOD2 gene was first reported in relation to autosomal dominant Blau syndrome in 2001 (Miceli-Richard et al., PMID 11528384). At least 20 unique missense variants have been reported in clinical cases with up to 80% of Blau syndrome associated with two recurrent NOD2 variants: p.Arg334Trp and p.Arg334Gln (Cantarini et al., 2014 PMID 25182201). Evidence supporting this gene-disease relationship includes case-level data, segregation data and experimental data.

Variants in this gene have been reported in at least nineteen probands in twelve publications (Hugot et al., 2001 PMID 11528384; Miyachi et al., 2005 15459013; Nakahata et al., 2009 PMID 19116920; Wouters et al., 2009 PMID 19479837; Shen et al., 2017 PMID 28721627; Williams et al., 2002 PMID 12428248; Santos-Juanes et al., 2007 PMID 17916199; Cirak et al., 2010 PMID 20084402; Pramono et al., 2019 PMID 31543536; Li et al., 2019 PMID 31803699; Nielsen et al., 2016 PMID 17207093). Wang et al. (2002 PMID 12428248) performed linkage analysis on ten families with Blau syndrome and reported a combined LOD score of 5.67. De novo variants have also been reported. The mechanism of disease is unknown. In vitro experiments suggest variants lead to a gain of function and ligand independent activation of NOD2 (Monie et al., 2014 PMID 25093298); however, patient cell and mouse model data suggest a downregulation of NOD2 signalling pathways. This gene-disease association is supported by data from patient cells which point to a disruption of NOD2 signalling pathways (Rosenbaum et al., 2011 PMID 21296813; Lee et al., 2010 PMID 20052476; Saito et al., 2017 PMID 28587749). Mouse models also showed partial recapitulation of aspects of disease (Davey et al., 2015; PMID 21296813). In summary, NOD2 is definitively associated with autosomal dominant Blau syndrome. This has been repeatedly demonstrated in both the research and clinical diagnostic settings, and has been upheld over time.

evidence.dc:description: assumed de novo variant with functional evidence.

evidence.rdfs:label: Leong 2019 case report
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: Multiple red papules that first became evident at the age of 10 months, at 18 months the baby had erythematous papules present on the entire body surface, sparing only palms and soles. Articular involvement was found with boggy synovial thickening of both ankle joints, wrists, and all the fingers from 12 months.

evidence.dc:description: De novo missense variant with functional evidence

evidence.rdfs:label: Zheng 2019 case report
evidence.phenotypeFreeText:
The proband has a history of soft tissue swelling involving the third digit of left hand, bilateral wrists and ankles from the age of 2 years. Pathology of the finger mass revealed abundant multinucleated giant cells consistent with GCTTS. She began to show features of polyarticular arthritis by age 7.
Absence of dermatitis and uveitis.

evidence.dc:description: De novo variant with functional evidence

evidence.rdfs:label: Milman 2006 Case report
evidence.detectionMethod: Candidate gene by direct sequencing, NOD exon and intronic boundaries of exon 4.
evidence.phenotypeFreeText:
Monozygotic twins with symptoms of exanthema, arthritis/periarthritis started at 1 year of age, and were followed by uveitis at 7–10 years of age.
20 years at report
Twin 1, clinical course:The disease started at 1 year of age with maculopapular exanthema spreading over the entire body. followed by enlargement of the peripheral
lymph nodes, periarticular swelling of the dorsum of the left hand and periarticular swelling of the dorsum of the right foot. There was intermittent lowgrade fever. At 1.3 years of age, a skin biopsy showed epithelioid cell granulomas. 
Eye examinations were normal until 9.8 years, when panuveitis was first observed in the left eye and soon progressed into bilateral intraocular inflammation. Twin 2 showed a similar clinical course.

evidence.dc:description: Score reduced as ethinicty of the family is not reported.

evidence.rdfs:label: Blau 01:44
evidence.detectionMethod: Direct sequencing of NOD2 (exons and exon/intron boundaries.

evidence.dc:description: No functional evidence of gene impact.

evidence.rdfs:label: Family 15: subject 25
evidence.detectionMethod: Merged data from two prospective cohorts and systematic review of medical records of interest. Variant detection methodology not given
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: Pediatric granulomatous disease, Table 1. Arthritis, mild uveitis, rash.

evidence.dc:description:
The variant is located within the central NOD domain of the NOD2 protein. 
Function Not scored : HEK 293T cells were cotransfected with a NOD2 mutant together with the NF-kappa B reporter plasmid and internal control plasmid, and NF-kappa B reporter activity was measured after 12 hours of incubation with or without muramyldipeptide (MDP; 5g/ml). The Cys495Tyr showed a 300 fold increase in ligand independent NF kappa B activation. Basal NF kappa B activation was classed as high compared to other NOD2 variants that were tested. Similar overexpression data reported by 25093298:Parkhouse et al. (2014) .

evidence.rdfs:label: Patient 20
evidence.detectionMethod: Candidate gene by direct sequencing, NOD exons and intronic boundaries.
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: The individual presented with symptoms from 1 year of age which included intermittent fever, a skin rash described as multiple lichenoid papules and scaly erythematous plaques; polyarticular arthritis. At the last exam, age 6 years, the case had not developed any ocular lesions and had normal visual acuity. The case was treated with systematic steroid therapy from the age of onset.

evidence.dc:description: Functional evidence for the variant no scored, see 19116920:Okafuji et al. (2009). Note that this case is from a different population to the Okafuji et al. (2009) case suggesting a recurrent variant.

evidence.rdfs:label: Family 23: subject 34
evidence.detectionMethod: Merged data from two prospective cohorts and systematic review of medical records of interest. Variant detection methodology not given.
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: Moderate uveitis indicating presence of complications and preserved vision with correction, polyarthritis, fever, skin rash.

evidence.dc:description: Variant is absent from 100 Japanese controls. Function: see above

evidence.rdfs:label: Patient 1
evidence.detectionMethod: Candidate gene by direct sequencing, NOD exons and intronic boundaries.
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: Age of onset 2 years of age, skin rash, uveitus, arthritis, lung involvement. The case's first symptom was atopic dermatitis.

evidence.dc:description:
The variant is located in the NBD domain at a highly conserved residue. 
Function: PMID: 25093298; Parkhouse et al. show ligand independent activation of NFkappaB when a NOD2 cDNA construct carrying this variant is overexpressed in HEK293 cells (Table 1, fig 1). Functional data could not be scored, overall score reduced to 0.1

evidence.rdfs:label: Family 1:5
evidence.detectionMethod: 11 exons and the flanking intronic sequences of CARD15 (EMBL accession number AJ303140) were screened.
evidence.phenotypeFreeText:
uveitis, skin lesions, joint inflammation
The variant was inherited from an affected father, who expressed skin lesions and joint inflammation. Pedigree given in Figure 1. Insufficient segregation data to score.

evidence.dc:description:
Highly conserved residue in the NBD domain, 
Function: 20052476: Martin et al. (2009): PMBC cell lines were derived from Blau syndrome patients heterozygous for p.Arg334Trp (3 affecteds from 1 family) showed impaired cytokine release (IL-1β, TNFα, and IL-12/23p40) compared to controls when treated with MDP or TLR agonists. 
Function: 20052476: Son et al. (2010):Peripheral blood mononuclear cells from a female BS patient heterozygous the recurrent 1000C>T (p.Arg334Trp) were analyzed for their ability to produce pro- and antiinflammatory cytokines in the presence and absence of MDP, PGN, and lipopolysaccharide (LPS).  Basal level of TNF alpha and IL-10 in unstimualted cells was low for both patient cells and controls. Upon stimulation with MDP, LPS, and PGN, the cells from the BS patient produced much lower levels of TNF-a, IL-10, G-CSF, and IFN-c than the controls. (Ratio less than 1 BS/control- see Fig2). 
Note: Recurrent variant; Rose et al. reported 18 cases that carried the Arg334Trp variant.
Function, not scored: 25093298:Parkhouse et al. (2014)  of NOD2 cDNA carrying the variant with or without a wildtype construct showed an increase in ligand independent NF-kappaB activity compared to wildtype (Fig 1) indicating that the variant causes autoactivation of NOD2.

evidence.rdfs:label: Family 4: 8
evidence.detectionMethod: Candidate gene by direct sequencing, NOD exons and intronic boundaries.

evidence.dc:description: Recurrent variant.

evidence.rdfs:label: Akil 2010 Case report
evidence.detectionMethod: Candidate gene by direct sequencing, NOD exons and intronic boundaries.
evidence.phenotypeFreeText:
A 14-year-old girl presented with complaints of growth retardation and recurrent symmetric arthritis of the proximal interphalangeal and metatarsophalangeal joints. She had bilateral cataracts
due to recurrent uveitis, camptodactyly persistent erythematous rash and ichthyosis. She had been exhibiting symptoms of arthritis for 7 years and of recurrent uveitis for 5 years. 
Granulomatous inflammation was observed in her skin biopsy specimen. 
Other: The patient developed renal failure and was diagnosed with RCC during the disease course. 
FH: Her two sisters and mother were affected with various combinations of these conditions: symmetric polyarthritis, uveitis (one of her sisters is blind), and skin involvement.

evidence.dc:description: Function:- not scored.Transfection of NOD2 cDNA carrying the variant with or without a wildtype construct showed an increase in ligand independent NF-kappaB activity compared to wildtype (Fig 1)

evidence.rdfs:label: Patient 5
evidence.detectionMethod: Candidate gene by direct sequencing, NOD exons and intronic boundaries.
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: early-onset sarcoidosis. First diagnosed at 1 year, skin rash, uveitus, arthritis. Positive Kveim test.

evidence.dc:description:
c.1001G>A (p.Arg334Gln) is located at a conserved residue within the NBD domain. 
20052476: Martin et al. (2009): PMBC cell lines were derived from Blau syndrome patients heterozygous for c.1001G>A (p.Arg334Gln) showed impaired cytokine release (IL-1β, TNFα, and IL-12/23p40) compared to controls. 
25429073: Dugan et al. (2015) Peripheral blood derived macrophages obtained from two different patients with Blau syndrome heterozygous for Arg334Gln, when stimulated with MDP showed impaired release of IL-6 or IL-8 and a reduction or absence of phosphorylated p38. The data indicated that MDP triggered MAPK pathway was not activated and that there was no activation of NF-kappa B activation (Fig 5).
Note this is a recurrent variant, PMID:19479837: Rose et al. (2009) reported this variant in 18 unrelated affected individuals.
Function (not scored): Parkhouse et al. show ligand independent activation of NFkappaB when a NOD2 cDNA construct carrying this variant is overexpressed in HEK293 cells (Table 1, fig 1).

evidence.rdfs:label: Family 2: 10
evidence.detectionMethod: Candidate gene by direct sequencing, NOD exons and intronic boundaries.

evidence.dc:description: Function Not scored:Transfection of NOD2 cDNA carrying the variant with or without a wildtype construct showed an increase in ligand independent NF-kappaB activity compared to wildtype (Fig 1)(25093298:Parkhouse et al. (2014)

evidence.rdfs:label: Patient 7
evidence.detectionMethod: Candidate gene by direct sequencing, NOD exons and intronic boundaries.
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: early-onset sarcoidosis, diagnosed at 6 months of age, skin rash, uveitus, arthritis.

evidence.dc:description: No functional data however this may be a recurrent variant; Matsuda et al. 2020 A retrospective cohort of 50 Japanese patients with Blau syndrome associated with NOD2 variants were assessed, nine patients were heetrozygous for the p.R587C variant (two familial and five sporadic).

evidence.rdfs:label: Family 24 subject 35
evidence.detectionMethod: Merged data from two prospective cohorts and systematic review of medical records of interest. Variant detection methodology not given.
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: Pediatric granulomatous disease, Table 1. Arthritis, severe uveitis, no rash, fever, inflammatory optic neuropathy.

evidence.dc:description: Functional evidence see above.

evidence.rdfs:label: Coto-Segura case report 2007
evidence.detectionMethod: Direct sequencing of NOD2 exon and exon intronic boundaries
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: early-onset sarcoidosis (EOS) with simultaneous cutaneous and articular symptoms. nonpruritic skin rash on the face, subcutaneous nodules over the joints which she had had since she was 12 months old. symmetric polyarthritis affecting her elbow, wrist, knee, ankle and proximal interphalangeal joints. The articular swelling increased slowly and the patient refused to walk, not because of pain, but because of limited joint mobility.

evidence.dc:description: Functional evidence, see above

evidence.rdfs:label: Family 1: III:1
evidence.phenotypeFreeText:
Chronic polyarthritis involving bilateral metacarpophalangeal (MCP) and proximal interphalangeal (PIP) joints of the hands, wrists, elbows, knees, and ankles accompanied by papular rashes on four extremities since the age of 6. She also had intermittent fever since then. Disease-modifying anti-rheumatic drugs (DMARDs) such as methotrexate and leflunomide combined with low-dose prednisone had no effect. At 12 years of age, she developed persistent bilateral panuveitis, which was resistant to the combination of cyclosporine and corticosteroids. Over the years, her polyarthritis resulted in flexion contractures of her third, fourth, and fifth fingers of both hands (camptodactyly) (Fig. 2a) and persistent swelling of both knees, and her uveitis caused atrophy of both eyeballs and eventually complete loss of vision. The patient denied any symptoms suggestive of inflammatory bowel disease (IBD), such as prolonged diarrhea or abdominal pain, melena, hematochezia, or perianal lesions. She also denied manifestations more specific to YAOS, such as distal lower extremity swelling or sicca-like symptoms. 32 years at report.
Figure 1, Pedigree shows seven affected individuals, all heterozygous for the variant. Disease manifestation is variable between affected family members for the skin rash and uveitis. Insufficient evidence to score segregation.

evidence.dc:description: Recurrent variant with functional evidence, see above. Score reduced as this is a second case of Chinese origin, there was not comment regarding haplotype analysis

evidence.rdfs:label: Family 2 II:4
evidence.phenotypeFreeText:
dermatitis and bilateral panuveitis since the age of 7,
persistent polyarthritis since 13.
Figure 3 Pedigree shows 4 affected family members with variable phenotype expression of the arthritis and skin rash, all expressed the uveitis phenotype. Insufficient evidence to score segregation.

evidence.dc:description: Recurrent variant see above. Score reduced, patient from Germany with this variant  has already scored. Could consider increasing to 0.5 because the report states that haplotype analysis confirmed an independent mutation event, however data was not shown.

evidence.rdfs:label: Family 3: 3
evidence.detectionMethod: Candidate gene by direct sequencing, NOD exons and intronic boundaries.
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: skin lesions, uveitis, joint inflammation, campodactyly.

evidence.dc:description:
Not all genes in the linkage region were sequenced.
Note: The LOD score of 5.67 was calculated using the combined data of 10 families reported here.
evidence.rdfs:label: Blau01

evidence.dc:description: The KO mouse model shows a susceptibility to uveitis, one of the variable phenotypes observed in Blau syndrome.Score reduced to reflect partial recapitulation of disease.

NOD2 deficiency results in increased susceptibility to peptidoglycan-induced uveitis in mice.
NOD2 KO mice were injected with PGN and inflammation was assessed by intravital microscopy.
NOD2 deficiency resulted in increased sensitivity to PGN as the number of rolling, adhering, and infiltrating leukocytes was significantly increased compared to wildtype (WT) mice treated with PGN (Fig. 2). Histopathology revealed exacerbated
inflammation, as a quantitative increase in the number of leukocytes within the aqueous and vitreous of both the anterior and posterior segments from NOD2 KO eyes compared with WT controls (Figs. 3A, 3B).
evidence.rdfs:label: Nod2 knockout mouse model of uveitis

evidence.dc:description: The loss of response to MDP challenge is also observed with peripheral blood derived macrophages, from patients harbouring NOD2 R334Q and R334W variants. Points reduced, biochemical recapitulation of disease only.

Targeted homologous recombination was used to introduce the Nod2 p.Arg314Gln variant into the mouse genome. Nod2 p.Arg314Gln is equivalent to the recurrent NOD2 p.Arg334Gln associated with Blau syndrome. 
The p.Arg314Gln mice(hets and homs) did not show any gross abnormalities of the skin, inflammatory changes in the eyes, or cathepsin activation indicative of arthritis in mice up to 36 weeks of age.
The inflammatory response of the mutant mice was tested by MDP challenge, wildtype mice responded with a 3 fold increase in IL-6, however the KI mice did not show any alteration in the  basal IL-6 levels (fig 2a). Control Nod2 knock out mice did not respond to MDP challenge. These data were repeated with an intraocular MDP challenge. 
At a cellular level: Bone marrow derived macrophages cultured from WT, +/R314Q, R314Q/R314Q and KO Nod2 mice (primed with poly(I;C) to enhance NOD2 expression) were stimulated with MDP. An increase in IL-6 production was seen in the WT cells, and was reduced in a gene dosage dependent manner in the other genotypes, NOD2 KO cells showed no response. (Fig 3.)
MDP-induced NOD2 activity leads to the ubiquitination of the kinase RIP2, which is necessary for downstream signal transduction events in the NF-kB and MAPK pathways: Fig 3. In BMDM cells, stimulated with MDP, levels of polyubiquitinated RIP2 were reduced in the R314Q heterozygous lines, and absent from the homozygous line.
evidence.rdfs:label: Knock-in mouse model

evidence.dc:description: This experiment shows a disruption of the normal NOD2 signalling pathway and regulation of inflammatory cytokines in patient cells.

iPSC lines derived from 2 patients with Blau syndrome with a heterozygous p.Arg334Trp NOD2 mutation (Blau1-R334W and Blau2-R334W,) were differentiated into macrophage cell lines. Fig 3. IFN-gamma–dependent NF-kB activation and NF-kB nuclear translocation, independent of MDP ligand, is enhanced in iPS-MPs with Blau syndrome–associated mutant NOD2. This result was repeated using patient monocyte-derived macrophages. IFN-g priming significantly increased IL-6, IL-8, and TNF-alpha production from the patient-derived Mo-MPs in a ligand-independent manner compared to control cells.
evidence.rdfs:label: Patient iPSC-derived macrophages

evidence.dc:description:
Many other members of the NLR (Nod-like receptor) family of pattern recognition receptors have been associated with multisystemic imflammatory disorders, for example: 
NLRP3 is associated with a spectrum inflammatory disorders: 1) Muckle-Wells syndrome (MWS) AD, MIM:191900, is characterized by episodic skin rash, arthralgias, and fever associated with late-onset sensorineural deafness and renal amyloidosis; 2)Chronic infantile neurologic cutaneous and articular (CINCA)syndrome  AD, MIM:607115, is a severe chronic inflammatory disease of early onset, characterized by cutaneous symptoms, central nervous system involvement, and arthropathy (AD). Familial cold inflammatory syndrome 1 (AD)	MIM:120100 characterized clinically by recurrent attacks of a maculopapular rash associated with arthralgias, myalgias, fever and chills, and swelling of the extremities after exposure to cold.
NLRP1: Autoinflammation with arthritis and dyskeratosis (AR/AD) MIM:617388: Autoinflammation with arthritis and dyskeratosis is characterized by recurrent fever, widespread skin dyskeratosis, arthritis, elevated biologic markers of inflammation, and mild autoimmunity with a high transitional B-cell level.
Review article: NOD2 is a member of the NLR (Nod-like receptor) family of pattern recognition receptors and plays a key role in the innate immune system.
evidence.rdfs:label: Review of NOD2 biochemical function

evidence.dc:description: Expression is consistent with the sites of inflammation pbserved in disease (joints, eye, skin)

https://www.proteinatlas.org/ENSG00000167207-NOD2/tissue, summary of RNA and protein expression sources. Expression is reported in the skin, eye, blood, bone marrow/lymphoid tissue. This is consistent with reports in the literature.
evidence.rdfs:label: Human Protein Atlas
